channel.title: PCWorld Latest Technology News
channel.description: Tech news and updates by PCWorld. Focused on computers and consumer electronics, topics include computer hardware, software, wireless, digital entertainment, security and anti-virus and gadgets.

item.title: Refreshed MacBook Pros May Boast Retina Display
item.description: Intel reveals that its Ivy Bridge CPU is built for Retina display computers, hinting that Apple's redesigned range of MacBook Pros will support the higher resolution used on the newest iPad.

item.title: LogMeIn Takes on Dropbox With 'Cubby' Cloud Storage
item.description: Cloud storage leader Dropbox might have serious competition at last. LogMeIn has announced the beta of its rival 'Cubby' service.

item.title: Reconsidering Prepaid Cell Phones
item.description: Analysis: A prepaid phone may be simply a stopgap, or a way around the high costs, two-year contractual handcuffs, and other difficulties of most current postpaid carriers.

item.title: Google Settles Gmail Trademark Dispute in Germany
item.description: Google has obtained control of the Gmail trademark in Germany, according to the German trademark office, and the legal battle for the related domain name is also...

item.title: Dude, You’ve Just Been 'Likejacked' by the Fortune 500
item.description: Facebook 'Likejacking' scams can fool even the savviest users. But behind the scammers lie some of the powerful marketing firms in the world.

item.title: Presented By:
An 'Eazy' Way to Guard Your Privacy
item.description: A new site called Priveazy aims to make protecting your data on Facebook and everywhere else simple and effective. It might well succeed.

item.title: 10 Questions for EdgeCast CFO Mike Kleiman
item.description: Name: Mike Kleiman

item.title: Samsung Sets Launch Date For Galaxy S III Smartphone
item.description: Samsung sent out media invites to a launch event on May 3 in London, where the company is expected to introduce the Galaxy S III.

item.title: Internet Explorer, Windows Phone Due Updates This Year
item.description: A leaked Microsoft roadmap reveals a 2013 launch target for Office 15, and other update plans and schedules.

item.title: RIM's Ex-Chief Aimed to Divorce BlackBerry Devices, Services
item.description: CEO Jim Balsillie urged shifting the company from its dependence on BlackBerry hardware in favor of a future built as much on outsourcing data as selling devices, it is revealed.

item.title: Apple Fails to Reach Agreement With Australian Competition Regulator
item.description: Apple failed in a mediation session on Monday to reach agreement with Australia's competition regulator on remedies for allegedly misleading consumers about the...

item.title: Apple and Chinese Environmental Group to Audit Factory for Pollution Concerns
item.description: Apple and a Chinese environmental group for the first time plan to jointly audit one of the company's supplier factories in China, in what could lead to more...

item.title: UK Charges Teenager for Alleged Jamming of Anti-terrorist Hotline
item.description: A 17-year-old arrested after a series of prank phones calls and denial-of-service attacks directed toward an anti-terrorist alert hotline was charged on...

item.title: Twitter Tech Support: How Effective Is Tweeting a Tech Problem?
item.description: Companies do answer customer support questions sent via Twitter. Here's how they handle it and how to be heard when you tweet your problem.

item.title: What's Next with Gaming Consoles
item.description: Analysis: Word is that Sony will be first to market with the PlayStation 4, and that Microsoft's Xbox 720 has 16 cores to entice gamers.

item.title: BlackBerry Still Beats Android on Security, Analysis Finds
item.description: RIM's struggling BlackBerry remains the clear leader in mobile security with market share leader Android lagging badly, an analysis of the top four platforms reveals.

item.title: Instagram: Bubble, Bubble, High Tech Trouble?
item.description: Shrewd business or a poke at a bubble -- Pundits are divided over the market meaning of Facebook's latest purchase.

item.title: Low Supplies of Retina Display Limits iPad Shipments, Analyst Says
item.description: Foxconn factory investigations and high demand challenge Apple, which is still expected to sell more than 60 million iPads in 2012.

item.title: App Draw: Will Paper for iPad be the Next Instagram?
item.description: The design app available from Apple's App Store makes it easy to create beautiful things and share them on social networks.

item.title: Presented By:
Hospitals Seeing More Patient Data Breaches
item.description: More of those problems are originating from laptops and mobile devices rather than a human slip-up in handling paper documents.

item.title: Is iOS Secure Enough for the Enterprise?
item.description: With RIM having recently stated its intention to refocus on the business market, the question has been raised whether Apple's progress into the enterprise could be stalled.

item.title: Google Hit With FCC $25K Fine Over Street View Data Collection
item.description: At issue is the finding nearly two years ago that Google Street View cars had been collecting payload data from unprotected Wi-Fi networks via code written for an experimental project.

item.title: Create a Photo Greeting Card in Pages '09
item.description: Here's how you can create an original photo greeting card for an inkjet printer in less than 20 minutes.

item.title: Fenway Park Goes High-Tech at 100
item.description: A question-and-answer session with Steve Conley, IT director for the Boston Red Sox, about the ballpark's use of Metro Ethernet, Wi-Fi, and more.

item.title: Proposal: Open Source Life, Not Death Sentence, for Windows XP
item.description: Analysis: Microsoft is pushing some stalwart products onto extended support, but instead of shutting out Windows XP, why not set it free?

item.title: China Launches Most DDoS Attacks, Report Says
item.description: China remains the top source country for Distributed Denial of Service attacks, according to Prolexic Technologies Quarterly Global DDoS Attack Report.

item.title: Low Android Revenues No Worry for Google
item.description: CEO dismisses concerns about Android's strategic value as a "short-term" issue, saying developing and distributing Android is about much more than the bottom line.

item.title: 1 in 5 Americans are 'Internet Innocents'
item.description: A survey by the Pew Internet and American Life Project reveals that 20 percent of Americans live in a world without cyberspace and don't expect to move anytime soon.

item.title: Intel's Ivy Bridge Launch Hints of Refreshed MacBook Pro
item.description: Apple is suspected to be the first manufacturer to launch an Ivy Bridge-equipped laptop, before new ultrabooks adopt the chip in May.

item.title: Friday the 13th and the Cracked iPad
item.description: The replacement cost stung, but Apple's not in the business of throwing free iPads at everyone who walks by the store.

item.title: Bugs & Fixes: Opening Old AppleWorks and Word Documents
item.description: What if a file's data format is so ancient that you no longer have any applications that can read the format? Here's a solution.

item.title: Airtoggle Saves Menu-bar Space, Toggles Wi-Fi From the Keyboard
item.description: For many people -- especially those using laptops with crowded menu bars -- the best part of Airtoggle is that you can easily disable and enable Wi-Fi without having to keep Apple's Wi-Fi menu extra enabled.

item.title: Are You Ready for a 'Quantified Life'?
item.description: One vision of the future puts your phone's sensor data in the hands of megacorporations. But what if you were in control of it?

item.title: MegaUpload Founder Causes Uproar Over Lawyer Choice
item.description: The shuttered file-sharing website hired attorney Andrew Schapiro, but his firm's previous participation in cases involving movie, TV show and software companies has raised conflict of interest concerns.

item.title: Presented By:
Nokia Answers Lumia 900 User Complaints with Software Update, Bill Credit
item.description: The credit effectively means anyone who was on the fence about whether to try out the Windows Phone platform can essentially get on board for free if they buy one before the offer runs out.

item.title: CISPA Monitoring Bill: Just the Facts
item.description: The Cyber Intelligence Sharing and Protection Act, or CISPA, would give private companies new ways to share information about cyber-threats with the U.S. government, and vice versa.

item.title: 5 Ways to Put LinkedIn to Work for Your Business
item.description: From increasing your company's visibility to gathering intelligence, LinkedIn can help your business succeed in multiple ways.

item.title: Flashback Malware Puts Apple in Security Spotlight: Experts Weigh In
item.description: Increased market share coupled with Apple's lack of transparency are largely to blame for an uptick in Mac security problems, say experts.

item.title: The New Kindle Touch Upgrade: How to Get It Now
item.description: The upgrade will roll out over Wi-Fi during the next several weeks but why wait? We show you how to get it now.

item.title: History's 10 Most Influential Robots
item.description: Ever wondered where modern-day robots originated? Check out this list of some of the most significant robots created.

item.title: Google Adds New Options for Viewing Data in Fusion Tables
item.description: Google is trying to popularize the somewhat obscure art of data visualization.

item.title: Asus to Ship Quad-core Transformer Pad 300 Tablet on April 22
item.description: Asus' latest Transformer Pad 300 will start shipping in the U.S. on April 22, the company said Friday.

item.title: VMware Official Fires Back at Open Source Cloud Vendors
item.description: After all the talk of open source clouds news from the past few weeks, VMware officials have finally responded.

item.title: 3 Tips for Actually Making Money Making Mobile Apps
item.description: Let's face it: Your prospects of becoming an overnight billionaire by inventing the next Instagram aren't good.

item.title: Why Open Source Is the Key to Cloud Innovation
item.description: Free and open source software (FOSS) have become pervasive in computing over the past 25 years.

item.title: Coming Soon: Ad Offers in Your Facebook News Feed
item.description: Facebook will roll out the Groupon-like deals to page owners gradually over the next few months.

item.title: Life on Mars? We’ve Been Wrong Before
item.description: A new research paper suggests that the Viking 2 mission to Mars may have found evidence of life after all. But let's not jump to conclusions here...

item.title: Why Switching OS Platforms Is Not a Security Fix
item.description: The Mac platform now finds itself in the crosshairs of malware developers along with Windows, but that isn't a reason to switch to Linux. "Less targeted" doesn't equal "more secure".

item.title: Presented By:
Try Calligra 2.4 for a New Microsoft Office Alternative
item.description: With office, graphics, and management components, this new open source contender aims to provide 'the most comprehensive free suite anywhere,' its makers say.

item.title: Wall Street Beat: Tech Stocks Waver Despite Strong Sales News
item.description: Concerns about the economy appeared to outweigh promising sales news from major IT players including SAP and Google, as computer stocks, along with other...
